Content.audiotext: Welcome students, to the experiment – 'To prepare plant anatomy temporary slide' - system guided learning session.
In this session you will be guided to;
Navigate through the various features of this screen.
This should equip you with the knowledge essential to perform the simulation effectively.
In the welcome screen, the demo icon prompts you to click on it first.
If you click anywhere else on the screen this prompt disappears.
The left segment of the screen, which is referred as the shelf area has the equipments, needed for this experiment.
The simulation is performed on the right segment of the screen, which is referred as the work area.
Items from the shelf area can be dragged and dropped on the work area.
On the top of the screen, you can locate a row of icons.
Icons which are applicable to this experiment are, Instructions,
Help,
and About product.
Click on About Product icon to know about the experiment version, functionality aspects and the best screen resolution to view and perform the demo.
Click on Instructions, to display the instructions to the students.
You must to go through this carefully before you proceed with the simulation.
This will guide you thoroughly on how to perform the simulation.
Application is enabled with a help option to assist you, just in case you encounter any difficulty during your simulation.
At this juncture, click on Help.
What you should do next, will appear as a message.
Click on Reset, to clear the selected items from the screen, enabling you to begin the simulation from the beginning.
You can view demos on the screen features of this application and how to perform the simulation by clicking on Demo.
These demos will illustrate the screen features of this application and also will guide you how to perform the simulation using model data.
The learning session ends here.
Hope this learning session was interesting and also provided you informations on the layout features of the screen pertaining to this experiment - To prepare plant anatomy temporary slide.
